description: In this module, you will consider the question: what will Earth look like in 500 million years? You will use data from Earth and models of a fictional planet to explore plate tectonics.
display_title: Staging: What will Earth look like in 500 million years?
title: Staging: GEODE Module (Blue Plate Special)

activities.description:
In this activity, you will explore GPS data to learn how Earth's surface is broken into many moving pieces.

You will use today's GPS data to predict where Earth's continents were located in the recent past.

You will use Seismic Explorer, a data model, to explore the relationship between the edges of Earth's moving pieces and the locations of volcanoes and earthquakes. You will hypothesize about why earthquakes and volcanoes occur where they do.

You will explore paleogeographic maps that scientists have made to illustrate Earth's history. Finally, you will make predictions about what Earth might look like 500 million years in the future.

Thumbnail image: Palogeographic Maps by C.R. Scotese, © 2013, PALEOMAP Project, (www.scotese.com)
activities.name: Earth's moving surface

pages.name: Earth
pages.text:
The image below shows a picture of Earth from space. The large brown and green landmass is Africa. Antarctica can be seen at the bottom of the image (South Pole), covered in snow and ice.

Astronaut photograph AS17-148-22727 courtesy NASA Johnson Space Center Gateway to Astronaut Photography of Earth

Has Earth always looked like this? Will Earth continue to look like this in the future?

In this module, you will use evidence to make predictions about how Earth might look in 500 million years.

embeddable.prompt: How do you think Earth might look in 500 million years?
Explain your answer. Why do you think that?

pages.name: GPS stations
pages.text:
You might be familiar with GPS (Global Positioning Service) devices. GPS is commonly found in cell phones and car navigation systems.

GPS technology is also used in stations positioned around the globe. GPS station data provide information about how places on Earth are moving relative to each other. Some of the GPS station data are shown in the map, below. GPS stations are only placed on land because we don’t place stations underwater.

The green dots show the original positions of the stations. The yellow lines show the direction that each station is moving. The length of the line indicates how fast each station has moved in a year. These lines aren’t drawn to scale, but a longer line means faster movement than a shorter line.

It is hard to feel that the ground is moving when you are standing on it! GPS stations send information to satellites, which provide us with measurements of how much Earth’s surface is moving from orbit.

embeddable.credit: NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology GPS Time Series

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Are all of the GPS stations on Earth moving in the same direction?
What is your evidence?

pages.name: Back in time
pages.text:
GPS data show that Earth's surface is moving very slowly (only millimeters a year). Even so, if given enough time, (Earth is 4.5 billion years old), slow movements can cause big changes to happen!

Based on today's GPS readings, we can make predictions about where continents were in the past.

embeddable.credit: NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology GPS Time Series

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the current direction of motion, where was Africa located 10 million years ago?

choices.choice: Northeast of where it is now
Southwest of where it is now
About the same position as it is now

embeddable.prompt: Explain your answer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the current direction of motion, where was South America located 10 million years ago?

choices.choice: Southwest of where it is now
Southeast of where it is now
About the same position as it is now

embeddable.prompt: Explain your answer.

pages.name: Volcanoes and earthquakes
pages.text:
In addition to GPS data, geologists also use data about earthquakes and volcanoes to help them understand how Earth works.

Seismic Explorer is a tool that can visualize volcano and earthquake data by mapping it onto Earth’s surface.

The volcano data are already shown on the map as triangles. To visualize the earthquake data, press the Play button. The earthquakes will be displayed in the map in the order in which they occurred. Use the timeline to see the dates on which the earthquakes occurred.

To hide earthquake or volcano data so that you can focus on one at a time, click on the Data type menu and uncheck the feature that you don't want to see. Check the box to show the feature again.

If you lose your place, click on the globe icon to reset the view.

embeddable.prompt: Take a snapshot and circle where you see earthquakes happening in a line on Earth’s surface.
Take a snapshot and circle where you see volcanoes occur in a line on Earth’s surface.
Take a snapshot and circle where you see lines of both volcanoes and earthquakes in the same place.
What do you notice about the lines of earthquakes and volcanoes and where they seem to occur on Earth's surface?
What are your initial ideas about why earthquakes and volcanoes might happen in lines?

pages.name: Planet in motion
pages.text:
On the previous page, you used the Seismic Explorer model to view the patterns of earthquakes and volcanoes on Earth. 

Now we want you to take a look at a model that uses scientific principles to help us better understand the dynamics of Earth. It is called Tectonic Explorer, and it is a model of a fictional Earth-like planet with moving pieces that are made up of continents and ocean.

We want you to explore a little with the model and see what you notice about the way these pieces interact with each other.

Press the Start button to play the model. You can rotate the planet to see its different sides.

embeddable.prompt: What did you notice about the planet’s surface in Tectonic Explorer?
Describe what happens when two sections of the surface pieces move toward each other.
Describe what happens when two sections of the surface move away from each other.

pages.name: Earth in the past
pages.text:
GPS data, along with earthquake and volcano data, allowed scientists to make a model of what Earth looked like in the past.

The maps below illustrate the locations of Earth's continents and oceans over hundreds of millions of years. There are 15 maps representing Earth from today (0 Ma) to 514 million years ago (Ma or mya).

Click through the slideshow to see how Earth's surface changed over the past 514 million years. Note the locations of landmasses throughout the series. Also note how the location and size of oceans and seas changed over time.

embeddable.prompt:
Start with the Late Jurassic map (152 mya) and move forward in time.

Describe how South America and Africa moved compared to each other.
What happened to the South Atlantic Ocean over the same time period (Late Jurassic to Modern World)?

embeddable.hint: Look at the pattern of movement of Africa and Arabia in the last few slides.
embeddable.prompt: If you were to draw the next map (the one to follow the Modern World map), what do you think will happen to the position of Africa relative to Arabia?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will explore how some features on Earth were created by plate interactions. You will use Tectonic Explorer to model the formation of the features.

Thumbnail image: Andes Mountains – Punta Arenas. NASA - Public Domain, Link
activities.name: Interpreting Earth’s clues

pages.name: Using data to explain how Earth's features formed
pages.text:
Scientists now understand that Earth’s surface is in constant motion. This was one of the most important revolutions in scientific thought.

The constant motion of the pieces of Earth's surface is responsible for all of the landforms (mountains, hills, plains, basins, trenches, etc.) on Earth, as well as many of Earth's earthquakes and volcanoes.

There are landforms, earthquakes, and volcanoes even under the water, as you can see in this video from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

In this activity, you will explore how Earth’s surface movements are responsible for most of the features and geologic events on Earth.

pages.name: How did the Andes Mountains form?
pages.text:
The Andes Mountains form the longest continental mountain range in the world.

Along the Andes Mountains, we know (from GPS data) that a portion of Earth under the Pacific Ocean is moving towards the piece of Earth's surface on which the South American continent is found. 

What can we observe happening at the place where these two pieces come together? Let’s look closely at some data from this part of the world.

By Elemaki - Own work, CC BY 3.0, Link

embeddable.content:
Below is a geographic profile that provides information about the elevation of the land along the profile line (from point P1 to point P2 in the map).

The graph's y-axis shows the elevation above and below sea level (measured in meters) along that line. Sea level is at 0 meters, so negative numbers represent places underwater, or below sea level. Positive numbers represent places that are above water, or above sea level.

The graph’s x-axis shows distances in kilometers between points P1 and P2 on the map above.

embeddable.caption: Ryan, W.B.F., S.M. Carbotte, J.O. Coplan, S. O'Hara, A. Melkonian, R. Arko, R.A. Weissel, V. Ferrini, A. Goodwillie, F. Nitsche, J. Bonczkowski, and R. Zemsky (2009), Global Multi-Resolution Topography synthesis, Geochem. Geophys. Geosyst., 10, Q03014, doi:10.1029/2008GC002332.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: At what point on the geographic profile does the land elevation rise above sea level?

choices.prompt: The lowest elevation is shown to occur at 670 km on the profile line.
Correct! The land meets sea level (0 m) at about 740 km from point P1.
This is one of the highest elevations above sea level. Where is the elevation just at sea level (0 m)?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: How far from Point P1 is the lowest point on the geographic profile of the Andes?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? The lowest elevation is lower than -4200 m.
Correct! The lowest elevation on this profile occurs about 6700 km from Point P1.
Are you sure? The lowest elevation is lower than 4400 m.

embeddable.hint:
Watch the video on page 1 again.

Which place highlighted in the video is like the point 670 km from point P1? What is that feature called?
embeddable.prompt:
On the geographic profile, look at the 670 km mark on the x-axis.

What feature might be represented by this elevation change?

embeddable.content:
The Seismic Explorer is zoomed in to the same area that you just explored in the geographic profile data.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

The Seismic Explorer map type is called a relief map. This type of map shows the elevations of land with colors.

Use the Data type menu to show earthquakes and volcanoes in the Andes. To show earthquakes, check the Earthquakes box, and press the Play button.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
Use the information you collected from the geographic profile to examine the relief map in Seismic Explorer.

In the relief map in Seismic Explorer, what color represents the lowest point of the ocean?

choices.prompt: The light blue colors show the locations of shallower areas.
The blue colors show areas that are deeper than the light blue areas, but they're not the deepest areas!
Correct! The dark blue coloring shows the locations of the oceanic trenches, the lowest spots in the map.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: On the relief map in Seismic Explorer, what color represents the Andes Mountains?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? The yellow color shows land, but it doesn't show the locations of the highest-elevation land.
Correct! The brown color shows the location of the highest elevations, the Andes Mountain range.
Are you sure? The green color shows land, but it doesn't show the locations of the highest-elevation land.

embeddable.content: In Seismic Explorer, click Data Type and select Volcanoes. This will add triangles that show the locations of volcanoes on the map.

embeddable.prompt: Describe the pattern of volcanoes in the Andes.

embeddable.content: Return to the Data Type button on Seismic Explorer. Uncheck Volcanoes and select Earthquakes. Click Play to make the earthquake data appear as colored circles on the map.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, how deep are the earthquakes that have occurred in the Andes? (Select all correct answers.)

embeddable.content:
You can make a cross-section in Seismic Explorer to see the pattern of earthquakes below the surface.

Watch the video to learn how to make a cross-section in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.prompt:
Create a cross-section to show the earthquakes that are located in same place as the geographic profile line.

Take a snapshot of your cross-section.

On the snapshot, draw a picture of what you think the pieces of Earth are doing as they come together beneath the surface.

Describe the pattern of earthquakes that you can see in the 3D cross-section of the Andes.
Explain how this pattern helps you think about what is happening when the two pieces of Earth's surface come together.
What might you look for in another place on Earth to know if its surface pieces are moving towards each other?

pages.name: How did the Aleutian Islands form?
pages.text:
Part of the state of Alaska is a chain of small islands that separate the Bering Sea, to the north, from the Pacific Ocean, to the south.

How did this chain of islands form? Can you use evidence to determine if this place is where two plates are moving towards each other?

By Hillebrand Steve, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service - http://www.public-domain-image.com/public-domain-images-pictures-free-stock-photos/nature-landscapes-public-domain-images-pictures/island-public-domain-images-pictures/aleutian-islands-ocean-water.jpg, Public Domain, Link

embeddable.prompt: What evidence would you need to tell if two pieces of Earth’s surface are moving towards each other near the Aleutians?

embeddable.content:
We will start by looking at the geographic profile of the area, which provides clues about important land features along the chain of islands.

The graph's y-axis shows the elevation above and below sea level (measured in meters) along that line. Sea level is at 0 meters, so negative numbers represent places that are underwater, or below sea level. Positive numbers represent places that are above water, or above sea level.

The graph’s x-axis shows distances in kilometers between points P1 and P2 on the map above.

embeddable.caption: Ryan, W.B.F., S.M. Carbotte, J.O. Coplan, S. O'Hara, A. Melkonian, R. Arko, R.A. Weissel, V. Ferrini, A. Goodwillie, F. Nitsche, J. Bonczkowski, and R. Zemsky (2009), Global Multi-Resolution Topography synthesis, Geochem. Geophys. Geosyst., 10, Q03014, doi:10.1029/2008GC002332.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
In the geographic profile, a lot of the profile is below water.

At what distance between points P1 and P2 does the profile show the land above water?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? The elevation changes here, but is the land above sea level (0 m)?
Are you sure? Sea level is at 0 m. Is this location above sea level?
Correct! The elevation at this point is above sea level, indicating the presence of an island.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the geographic profile, where is the ocean deepest near the Aleutian Islands?

choices.choice: The ocean is deepest 500 km south of the islands.
choices.prompt: In the geographic profile, the island can be found about 530 km from point A. Where is the ocean the deepest?

choices.choice: The ocean is deepest 170 km south of the islands.
choices.prompt: Correct! The ocean is deepest at 360 km from Point P1. The island is 530 km from Point P1. This means that the deepest part of the ocean is located 170 km from the island.

choices.choice: The ocean is deepest 500 km north of the islands.
choices.prompt: Are you sure? Point P1 is located south of the islands. Where is the deepest point of the ocean?

choices.choice: The ocean is about the same depth for 500 km around the islands.
choices.prompt: Are you sure? The profile graph shows many different elevations from Point P1 to Point P2.

embeddable.content:
Now we will return to the Seismic Explorer, which is zoomed into a relief map of the Aleutian Islands, to look at earthquake and volcano data. 

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

Set the Data type menu to show earthquakes and volcanoes. To show earthquakes, check the Earthquakes box, and press the Play button.

Use the relief map and the earthquake and volcano data to answer the questions below.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, are there volcanoes in the Aleutians?

choices.prompt: Correct! The Aleutian Islands are a chain of volcanic islands.
Are you sure? Use the Data type menu to show volcanoes in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, how deep are the earthquakes that have occurred in the Aleutians? (Select all correct answers.)

choices.prompt: Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!

embeddable.hint: Remember that your cross section line should be drawn perpendicular to the line of earthquakes!
embeddable.prompt:
Create a cross-section of the earthquakes that is in same region as the geographic profile line.

Take a snapshot of your cross-section.
Describe the pattern that you see in the 3D cross-section.

The Andes Mountains and the Aleutian Islands are both examples of places where two pieces of Earth’s surface move towards each other.

Describe the earthquake, volcano, and landform patterns that the Andes and Aleutians have in common.

pages.name: Test your hypotheses with a model
pages.text:
So far in this activity, you have explored two regions on Earth where two pieces of Earth's surface are moving towards each other: the Andes Mountains and the Aleutian Islands. Scientists call these pieces of the Earth plates. Plates include parts of the Earth’s surface (crust) that are both above and below water.

You will use Tectonic Explorer, a model of an Earth-like planet, to explore how the moving plates can form areas like the Andes Mountains and the Aleutian Islands.

Tectonic Explorer will allow you to investigate how the moving plates of Earth's surface change over time, create landforms (mountains and trenches), and result in tectonic events (earthquakes and volcanoes). You will be able to see above and below the planet's surface in the model.

This exploration will help you to develop a more complete picture of what causes landforms, earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions to happen as two plates move towards each other.

Play the video below to learn how to set up the model.

embeddable.caption: How to set up Tectonic Explorer and make a cross-section

embeddable.content:
This model planet has been set up to have only two plates.

In Tectonic Explorer, on the plate on the right, create a continent that looks somewhat like South America where the Andes Mountains formed. Leave the plate on the left as just ocean (no continents), just like the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of South America.

Add forces to the plates (see video). Choose which plate will go under the other plate.

Draw a cross-section across the pink line that separates the two plates, perpendicular to the plate boundary. This will allow you to see what is happening beneath the surface as the plates come together.

embeddable.prompt: Take a snapshot of the model and cross-section that shows the creation of a mountain range like the Andes.
Describe how the two plates in Tectonic Explorer moved relative to each other to form the chain of mountains on the continent.

embeddable.content:
You just created a model of the Andes Mountains in Tectonic Explorer. A plate with just ocean and a plate with ocean and continent came together to form a mountain range with volcanoes and earthquakes.

Can you set up the Tectonic Explorer to form a chain of islands that looks like the Aleutian Islands?

embeddable.prompt:
Try to set up Tectonic Explorer to match the Aleutian Islands in a way that creates a chain of islands.

Take a snapshot of your best example of a chain of islands. Make sure to show a cross-section.
Describe how the two plates in Tectonic Explorer moved relative to each other to form the island chain.

Use the model to explain the data you saw earlier from the Andes and the Aleutians.

Include the connections between the model and:

• patterns of landforms (mountains & trenches) from the geographic profile
• patterns of volcanoes
• patterns of earthquakes and earthquake depths

pages.name: How did the Himalayan Mountains form?
pages.text:
The Himalayan mountain range, home of Mount Everest (the highest mountain on Earth), is located between India and Asia.

How did these large mountains form? Watch the video to see a paleomap reconstruction of the event, starting at 1:25.

This animation shows how India and Asia came together to form the Himalayan mountains and Tibetan plateau, as an ocean closed up between them.

The colors represent: blue - deep ocean, light blue - shallow water flooding the continental lowlands, green - lowlands, brown - mountains.

embeddable.credit: Scotese, C.R., 2013. Collision of India & Tectonic Evolution of Southeast Asia, PALEOMAP Project Animation, http://youtu.be/UkDzSZfWFAQ.

embeddable.hint: Think about what was happening at the surface (including the surface of the ocean floor!) and below the surface over time.
embeddable.prompt: Based on what you saw in the video, describe what happened to Earth's surface that enabled the formation of the Himalayas.

embeddable.content:
The video showed that, over a long period of time, India and Asia came together and formed the Himalayas.

Use Tectonic Explorer to create a model of how the Himalayas might have formed. Tectonic Explorer has been set up with continents and forces.

embeddable.prompt: How does the Tectonic Explorer model help you explain what happened in Earth’s history prior to, and during, the formation of the Himalayas?

embeddable.hint: Make sure to draw your cross-section across the pink boundary line.
embeddable.prompt:
What happens to the plate that India is on as it moves towards the boundary?

Describe the changes that happen on the surface and below the surface.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What happens when two continents meet at a plate boundary?

choices.choice: One continent goes under the other, pushing it down to make a trench.
choices.prompt: Are you sure? Look at a cross section in Tectonic Explorer. Is there a trench between the ccontinents?

choices.choice: One continent goes under the other, lifting it up to make mountains.
choices.prompt: Are you sure? Make a cross section in Tectonic Explorer and watch what happens below the surface as the continents come together.

choices.choice: The continents crash into each other and push up the edges to make mountains.
choices.prompt: Correct! Continents cannot go beneath each other, so they lift up at their edges to form mountains.

choices.choice: The continents stop moving and become fixed in place.
choices.prompt: Are you sure? Look at the video again. Did India stop moving north after it first met Asia?

embeddable.content:
It is time again to look at the earthquake and volcano data in the Seismic Explorer model, which is now zoomed in to the area around the Himalayas.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

embeddable.hint: Remember to make your cross section perpendicular to the line of earthquakes!
embeddable.prompt:
Make a cross section of the earthquakes in the Himalayas.

Take a snapshot of your cross section.

Describe the pattern that you can see in the 3D cross-section. 

How does this compare to what you saw in the Andes Mountains and Aleutian Islands?

Go back to 50 mya (2:20) in the video showing India colliding with Asia.

What do you think the earthquake pattern looked like along the boundary 50 million years ago?

What happened between 50 million years ago and now to make the earthquake pattern different?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will investigate how tectonic plates interact as a system. You will discover how plate interactions in one place affect plate interactions in many other places.

Thumbnail image: Oblique aerial view of San Andreas Fault (between white arrows) in southeastern Coachella Valley, near Red Canyon; view to the west. By Michael Rymer, U.S. Geological Survey. Public domain - https://www.usgs.gov/media/images/san-andreas-fault-se-coachella-valley
activities.name: What happens with a lot of moving plates?

pages.name: Earth's plate system
pages.text:
In Activity 2, you explored places on Earth where two plate edges are in contact with each other and one plate is being pushed under the other. The process of one plate going under another is called subduction. Subduction of one plate beneath another changes Earth’s surface. As you saw in the last activity, landforms, such as mountains and ocean trenches, form, and lines of earthquakes and volcanoes develop along these boundaries.

It is important to remember that Earth is not made up of just two plates, but lots of plates, all of them moving at the same time. In Activity 2, you looked in detail at what happens when two plates are moving towards each other. But those plates have other edges as well.

Since Earth is made up of lots of plates, it must be true that each plate touches all of the plates around it, and there must be different ways for plates to interact at these other kinds of boundaries,

In this activity, you will apply what you learned about patterns in earthquakes and volcanoes to explore the features associated with other types of plate interactions on Earth.

", "mediaType": "none", "mediaURL": "" } }

embeddable.content:
South America is a continent on one of Earth's plates.

Use the earthquake and volcano data to make a prediction about the boundaries of the plate on which South America sits.

embeddable.prompt:
Take a snapshot of the area that you think includes the plate on which South America sits.

Use the draw tools to trace an outline of the plate boundaries.
What evidence did you use from Seismic Explorer to locate the boundaries of the plate on which South America is located?

pages.name: What's happening along the boundary in the Atlantic Ocean?
pages.text:
On the previous page, you used earthquake and volcano data to sketch an outline of the plate that includes the South American continent. Part of the outline of this plate is in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.

You will use Seismic Explorer to describe the patterns in the seafloor surface features (topography), earthquakes, and volcanoes along this plate boundary.

embeddable.prompt: Take a snapshot that shows the earthquakes and volcanoes in the Atlantic Ocean.
Where are the earthquakes and volcanoes found in relationship to the landforms on the ocean floor?

Make a cross-section of the earthquakes in the Atlantic Ocean. Remember to draw your cross-section perpendicular to the line of earthquakes!

Take a snapshot of your cross-section.

embeddable.hint:
You can look back to Activity 2, page 2 where you first made a cross-section of earthquakes in the Andes.

Or you can create a new cross-section in Seismic Explorer, above.
embeddable.prompt: How does the pattern of earthquakes in the Atlantic Ocean compare to the pattern of earthquakes along the boundary that formed the Andes Mountains?

embeddable.content: Below is a geographic profile that provides information about the land elevation along the profile line (from point A to point B in the map) across the Atlantic Ocean.

embeddable.caption: Ryan, W.B.F., S.M. Carbotte, J.O. Coplan, S. O'Hara, A. Melkonian, R. Arko, R.A. Weissel, V. Ferrini, A. Goodwillie, F. Nitsche, J. Bonczkowski, and R. Zemsky (2009), Global Multi-Resolution Topography synthesis, Geochem. Geophys. Geosyst., 10, Q03014, doi:10.1029/2008GC002332.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the geographic profile, where are the deepest parts of the Atlantic Ocean?

choices.choice: about 0 km and about 6000 km from point P1
choices.prompt: Are you sure? 0 km is point P1, which on South America, and 6000 km is close to point P2, on Africa.

choices.choice: about 1600 km and about 4500 km from point P1
choices.prompt: Correct! The deepest parts of the Atlantic Ocean are around 1500 km and 4500 km from point P1.

choices.choice: about 2000 km and about 4000 km from point P1
choices.prompt: These areas are pretty deep, but they're not the deepest areas along this profile line.

choices.choice: about 2800 km and about 3200 km from point P1
choices.prompt: Are you sure? This area is the shallowest part of the Atlantic Ocean. The elevation is closest to sea level (0 m).

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the geographic profile, where is the Atlantic Ocean the shallowest?

choices.prompt: The ocean is pretty deep 1000 km from point P1.
The ocean is getting shallower 2000 km from point P1, but it is not the shallowest.
Correct! The ocean is the shallowest around 3000 km from point P1. This shallow area is known as the mid-Atlantic ridge.
The ocean is getting deeper 4000 km from point P1.
The ocean is pretty deep 5000 km from point P1.

embeddable.prompt: What do you notice about the shape of the geographic profile of the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
What do you think is happening under the Atlantic Ocean, where the two plates meet at the mid-ocean ridge?

The plates
Explain your choice using evidence from Seismic Explorer and the geographic profile.

pages.name: Model the South American plate
pages.text:
Scientists have named Earth's major plates. The name of the plate on which South America is located is called the South American plate. You will use Tectonic Explorer to investigate the interactions that happen on two edges of the South American plate.

Set up Tectonic Explorer to make a mountain chain like the Andes. (You did this previously in Activity 2.)

Place a continent on the right side, along the plate boundary (pink line). Leave the left plate with just oceanic crust.

Add forces and set which plate will go below the other to make a chain of mountains on the continent.

embeddable.hint:
Make sure the plates are moving towards each other along this boundary.

It should look similar to cross-sections you made in Activity 2.

When setting up Tectonic Explorer, make sure to place one continent on the very edge of the boundary, like the South American continent is right on the plate boundary with the Pacific Ocean.
embeddable.prompt:
Once you have created a mountain chain on the continent, make a cross-section perpendicular to the line of mountains.

On your cross-section, label the trench and mountains.

embeddable.hint: This boundary should have oceanic crust on both sides!
embeddable.prompt:
Now rotate the planet to look at the other edges of the plates at the boundary on the opposite side from where you put the continent.

Make a cross-section across this boundary. Take a snapshot.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What features do you observe at the oceanic-oceanic plate boundary? (Choose all that apply.)

choices.choice: volcanic islands forming at the boundary
thicker plates on each side of the boundary
thinner plates on each side of the boundary

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
Look at a location where oceanic plate material meets oceanic plate material from another plate in this model.

How are the plates moving relative to each other at this boundary?

The plates are moving

choices.prompt: Are you sure? Run the model and observe how the plates move.
Correct! At this boundary, the plates are moving away from each other.
Are you sure? Run the model and observe how the plates move.

embeddable.content: Compare what you observed in Tectonic Explorer to the geographic profile of the Atlantic Ocean (shown below).

embeddable.caption: Geographic profile of the Atlantic Ocean. South America is on the western side of the Atlantic Ocean (on the left). Africa is on the eastern side of the Atlantic Ocean (on the right).

embeddable.prompt:
Take a snapshot of the geographic profile of the Atlantic Ocean.

Where do you think the plate boundary is located on the profile?

Place an X on the profile line where you think the plate boundary exists.
Explain your answer. Why did you put the X where you did?

On the geographic profile of the Atlantic Ocean, there is actually a mountain range that forms where the plates move away from each other.

What did you observe at the plate boundary in Tectonic Explorer that could explain why mountains form where plates move away from each other?
What surface patterns (landforms like mountains and events like earthquakes & volcanoes) would you look for to identify a place on Earth where plates are moving away from each other?

pages.name: All of Earth's plate boundaries
pages.text:
So far, you have discovered that tectonic plates can move towards each other and away from each other. Geologists have classified plate boundaries based on how the plates on each side of the boundary move.

• When two plates move towards each other, the plate boundary between them is called a convergent boundary.
• When two plates move away from each other, the plate boundary between them is called a divergent boundary.

There is also a third type of plate boundary:

• When two plates move past each other, the plate boundary between them is called a transform boundary.

 

Based on USGS - [1], Public Domain, Link

In the ocean, transform boundaries are associated with divergent boundaries and mid-ocean ridges. These long mountain chains form a zigzag pattern on the seafloor.

 

Transform boundaries also link different types of plate boundaries.

California has a transform boundary where pieces of two plates are sliding past each other. The picture below shows the San Andreas fault, a part of the larger transform boundary that links a divergent boundary in the East Pacific Rise to a convergent boundary in the Pacific Northwest.

The San Andreas fault can be seen as a long deep crack in Earth's surface. On either side of the crack, there are lines of valleys and mountains.

By John Wiley User:Jw4nvc - Santa Barbara, California - Own work, CC BY 3.0, Link

embeddable.content:
Seismic Explorer shows the boundaries of Earth's major plates.

The three colors (teal, pink, and yellow) represent the three boundary types. Use the Key to explore the boundary types.

embeddable.prompt:
What do you notice about the locations of the plate boundaries and the locations of earthquakes and volcanoes?

Why do you think these patterns exist?

Earlier in this activity (page 1, question 1), you made a hypothesis about the location of the plate boundaries for the South American plate.

How well did your prediction match the actual locations of the plate boundary?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: How many plates touch the South American plate?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? Have you counted all of the plates around the South American plate?
Are you sure? Have you counted all of the plates around the South American plate?
Are you sure? Have you counted all of the plates around the South American plate?
Correct! There are many plates that touch the South American plate. Some are large (major) plates, and some are smaller plates.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Are all of the plates on Earth the same size?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? Some plates are very large, but others are very small.
Correct! Earth's plates come in all shapes and sizes.

pages.name: How do plates move and interact?
pages.text:
Earth's surface has dramatic mountains, beautiful valleys, complex and winding coastlines, undersea mountain ranges, and deep ocean trenches.

On this page, you will use Tectonic Explorer, now set up with five plates, to explore a more complicated set of plate interactions.

Set up different scenarios with this model. Try putting continents in different places. Try making different plates go over or under each other.

Make sure to pay attention to what happens on all of the plates on the planet – rotate the planet and observe all of its sides!

embeddable.prompt:
Find a place where two plates are moving away from each other (a divergent boundary).

Make a cross-section.

Take a snapshot.
What evidence is there that this place on the planet is a place where plates are moving away from each other (diverging)?

embeddable.hint: Use Seismic Explorer (on the previous page) to find places on Earth that are similar.
embeddable.prompt: What place on Earth (other than the middle of the Atlantic Ocean) is like the divergent boundary in Tectonic Explorer?

Find a place where two plates are moving towards each other (a convergent boundary).

Make a cross-section.

Take a snapshot.
What evidence is there that this place on the planet is a place where plates are moving toward each other (converging)?

embeddable.hint: Use Seismic Explorer (on the previous page) to find places on Earth that are similar.
embeddable.prompt: What place on Earth (other than the Andes Mountains in South America) is like the convergent boundary in Tectonic Explorer?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will explore complicated plate interactions and the mechanisms of plate motion.

 

Thumbnail image: By The original uploader was Harroschmeling at German Wikipedia - Transferred from de.wikipedia to Commons., CC BY-SA 3.0, Link
activities.name: What drives plate motion?

pages.name: Earth's complicated surface
pages.text:
Earth has eight major plates, ten minor plates, and dozens of microplates. In Activities 2 and 3, you saw that Earth's plates are moving in different directions at different speeds.

Something must be causing these plates to move. Just like anything else, if a plate is moving, it must be subject to a force that drives the motion. In this activity, you will explore the forces that move the plates.

embeddable.prompt:
What do you think is causing Earth's plates to move?

Do you have any evidence to support this idea?

pages.name: How are the plates moving?
pages.text:
Tectonic Explorer shows new plate material being formed at a divergent boundary and old plate material subducting back into the planet at a convergent boundary. Is there some connection between these locations and the forces driving plate movement?

The Tectonic Explorer model below is already set with a cross-section. When you start the model, you will see that the center of each plate is labeled with a number. (You may have to rotate the planet to see the number on each plate.) Run the model.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: How many plates are shown in the cross-section?

embeddable.hint: Restart the model to observe how each plate moves.
embeddable.prompt:
Take a snapshot of Tectonic Explorer that includes the cross-section.

Use the drawing tools to place arrows in the cross-section that illustrate the way that each plate is moving.
What else may be moving in the model to cause the planet's crust to move?

pages.name: Deep Earth
pages.text:
Earth has layers. The solid, rigid layer on which we live is called the crust. The crust lies on top of the mantle.

The mantle is solid, but less rigid than the crust, and can slowly flow. The mantle flows and moves in response to heating from deeper in the planet. The motion of the mantle is slow, and at any given moment it appears solid, but over millions of years, this seemingly-solid material does move and pulls the crust along with it.

embeddable.content:
The movement of mantle rock happens through a process called convection. During convection, hotter rock rises upwards through the mantle, and as a result, cooler rock is pushed down deeper into the mantle.

One way that scientists think about convection in the mantle is by creating computer simulations. In the simulation below, Earth is represented by the large blue sphere. A section has been cut away to show the inside. The red section in the center represents the core, which provides a source of heat energy.

As the simulation runs, you will see yellow and blue flowing up and down in the simulated mantle. These changing colors represent changes in temperature. As warmer (yellow) material moves up. As it reaches the level just below the surface, the material flows sideways and begins to cool (turning blue). Cooler (blue) material starts closer to the surface and sinks and warms (turning yellow).

embeddable.caption: Convection in a spherical shell, mimicking convection in the Earth mantle. The simulation corresponds to some 1.5 billion years of Earth history, run with the finite element code ASPECT (http://aspect.dealii.org).
embeddable.credit: Simulation by Wolfgang Bangerth, computed with the ASPECT code (https://youtu.be/j63MkEc0RRw)

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What plate boundary type would you expect to see where the warming mantle (yellow color) is rising up through the mantle?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What plate boundary type would you expect to see where the cooling mantle (blue color) is sinking back into the mantle?

embeddable.content: The image below shows a cross-section that extends deeper into the layer below the crust. The green layer is called the mantle. The crust, a solid, rigid layer, lies on top of the mantle. The continental crust is colored brown, and the oceanic crust is colored dark blue.

embeddable.prompt:
Take a snapshot of the image.

Use the drawing tools to draw arrows.

1. Show the direction that you think that the pieces of the planet (plates) are moving.

2. Show the direction that you think the mantle (the dark green layer) is moving.
Explain why you drew the mantle arrows the way that you did.

pages.name: Convection and plate movement
pages.text:
The plates that make up the Earth's crust are continually moving. The results of this movement are the distribution of landforms (mountains and mid-ocean ridges) and patterns of events (earthquakes and volcanic eruptions). The plates have moved as a result of convection found in the mantle.

Earth's plates move in different directions. The direction of movement and type of plate boundary is determined by the direction of flow of the convection currents in the mantle below the plate.

Explore the plate boundaries in Seismic Explorer, and consider how mantle convection determines the movement along each boundary.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Which part of the mantle convection process is likely to be occurring at the boundary between the Somali plate and the Australian plate?
Explain your answer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Which part of the mantle convection process is likely to be occurring at the boundary between the Nazca plate and the South American plate?
Explain your answer.

pages.name: New thinking on how plates move
pages.text:
Scientific knowledge does not remain the same forever. As scientists gather more data and evidence, they continue to improve their explanations of how the world works.

Scientists have known for a long time that convection in the mantle helps to move the plates, but it is only one of the processes that scientists think is responsible for explaining how plates move.

Two other processes scientists think move plates have to do with the force of gravity on parts of the plates and are called slab pull and ridge push. The video below will help you understand these new ideas about how plates move.

embeddable.caption: What are the forces that drive plate tectonics?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: At which type of boundary does ridge push occur?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: At which boundary type does slab pull occur?
How does gravity on a subducting plate cause plates to move?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will use data to make predictions about future Earth.

Thumbnail image: By NASA - http://sideshow.jpl.nasa.gov/mbh/all/images/global.jpg, Public Domain, Link
activities.name: What will Earth look like in the future?

pages.name: Predicting the future
pages.text:
As you have gone through the first four activities of this sequence, you have learned that Earth's tectonic plates are constantly moving. Many of Earth's features and events occur in predictable places.

When studying plate motion, geoscientists consider such questions as:

• If South America is part of a moving plate, where was it in the past?

• When did South America become a separate continent?

• When did the current plate boundaries develop?

Like geoscientists, you examined data from GPS stations to investigate how Earth's surfaces are moving today. You made models to explain how Earth's plates interacted to create different Earth features. You also looked at the locations of earthquakes and volcanoes.

In this activity, you will consider how plate tectonics might help explain features that are not on currently-active plate boundaries, and then you will use what you have learned to make predictions about what parts of Earth will look like in the future.

embeddable.prompt:
Geoscientists need to think about Earth in the distant past and consider how it will change in the future.

Based on what you know about Earth's plates, what data and evidence would you need to predict what the future of Earth might look like?

pages.name: Measuring motion at plate boundaries
pages.text:
Earthquake and volcano data provide evidence as to where plate boundaries are today.

Plate movement data is shown in Seismic Explorer, below. Click on the i for information about how fast the plates are moving along various boundaries.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: How fast is the Pacific plate moving towards Japan?

choices.prompt: The Pacific plate is moving 26 mm/yr south of Japan. How fast is it moving toward Japan?
The Pacific plate is moving 77 mm/yr north of Japan. How fast is it moving towards Japan?
Correct! The "i" nearest Japan shows that the Pacific plate is moving 83 mm/yr towards Japan.

embeddable.prompt: Describe the geologic features (landforms) that are connected to the plate motion near Japan.

embeddable.hint: To get the speed that continents on either side of the boundary are moving away from each other, add the two rates of motion.
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
At a divergent boundary, the arrows show the speed and direction that each plate is moving.

How fast are North America and Europe moving away from each other?

choices.prompt: Correct! The "i" shows that North America and Europe are each moving at a rate of 22 mm/yr. This means that North America and Europe are moving away from each other at twice this speed – 44 mm/yr.
This is the rate that North America is moving away from Africa. How fast is North America moving away from Europe?
This is the rate that South America is moving away from Africa. How fast is North America moving away from Europe?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Are all plates moving at the same rate?

choices.prompt: The length of the arrow shows how fast each plate is moving. Are all of the arrows the same length?
Correct! The arrows in Seismic Explorer show that plates are moving at different rates.

embeddable.hint:
Think about the forces that are responsible for plate motion.

You may want to go back to Activity 4 to review them.
embeddable.prompt: Why do you think some plates move faster than others?

pages.name: Why are the Appalachian Mountains there?
pages.text:
To predict the future, it helps to know think about how current Earth features formed.

The Appalachian Mountains can be found along the east coast of North America.

The photo shows the view looking southwest from the observation tower atop Mount Mitchell in North Carolina. Mount Mitchell is the highest point in the Appalachians and the highest peak in North America east of the Mississippi River.

By Ken Thomas - KenThomas.us(personal website of photographer), Public Domain, Link

Seismic Explorer is zoomed in to show the Appalachian Mountain chain. The relief map view shows the different elevations in different colors. The brown colors indicate the locations of the mountains along the Appalachian chain.

embeddable.prompt: Why do you think the Appalachian Mountains are there? How do you think they formed?

embeddable.hint: Use the Data type menu to show current plate boundaries.
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Is there a plate boundary near the Appalachian Mountains today?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: In the past, do you think that there was a plate boundary located near where the Appalachian Mountains are today?

embeddable.hint:
How did the Appalachian Mountains form? How do any mountains form?

What is the evidence for this having happened? Look at the other side of the current plate boundary for clues.
embeddable.prompt: Describe the story of the east coast of North America, starting with the formation of the Appalachian Mountains and ending with what's happening today.

pages.name: How did the Red Sea form?
pages.text:
The Red Sea is an inlet of water between Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. It formed within the last 50 million years. The paleogeographic map image, below, shows how Africa and Arabia were connected 30 million years ago, compared to today, when the Red Sea lies between Africa and Arabia.

What is happening to form the Red Sea? And what will happen in the future?

embeddable.content:
The geographic profile provides information about the elevation along the profile line (from point P1 to point P2 in the map).

The graph's y-axis shows the elevation above and below sea level (measured in meters) along that line. Sea level is at 0 meters.

embeddable.caption: Ryan, W.B.F., S.M. Carbotte, J.O. Coplan, S. O'Hara, A. Melkonian, R. Arko, R.A. Weissel, V. Ferrini, A. Goodwillie, F. Nitsche, J. Bonczkowski, and R. Zemsky (2009), Global Multi-Resolution Topography synthesis, Geochem. Geophys. Geosyst., 10, Q03014, doi:10.1029/2008GC002332.

embeddable.content:
The Seismic Explorer model is zoomed in to the same area.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

The Seismic Explorer map type is called a relief map. This type of map shows the elevations of land with colors.

Use the Data type menu to show earthquakes and volcanoes in the Red Sea. To show earthquakes, check the Earthquakes box, and press the Play button.

embeddable.prompt: Based on evidence from the geographic profile and Seismic Explorer, describe how the Red Sea formed.

embeddable.hint: What other area did you look at in Activity 2 or Activity 3 that is similar to the Red Sea?
embeddable.prompt: Describe the geologic landforms and patterns of earthquakes and volcanoes that you would expect to see at this location in 200 million years.

pages.name: Test your hypotheses with a model
pages.text:
Use Tectonic Explorer to think about the data that you just looked at (on the previous page) from the Red Sea (geographic profile and Seismic Explorer (earthquake and volcano data)).

Set up the model to test your prediction about what will happen in that location over 200 million years. Make a cross-section to see what happens below the surface.

embeddable.prompt: Take a snapshot of your original setup (before running the model).
Explain how this model represents the Red Sea now.

Let the model run for 200 million years. Watch the time counter at the bottom center of the model.

Take a snapshot.
How does the model confirm or contradict your predictions?

pages.name: What will Earth look like in 500 million years?

embeddable.hint: Your answer should include reference to the shape or size of the continents and their locations, using cardinal directions.
embeddable.prompt: Based on how plates are moving on Earth right now, explain how you think Africa, the Atlantic Ocean, and South America will look 500 million years in the future.
